content.description: This is a fun route that looks harder from the ground than it is.  I wouldn't hike in just for this little crag but if you are coming down from the upper crags it is worth a stop to do this route.
content.protection: Bolts to a tree anchor with slings and biners. Boulder up to the first bolt.  Some of the bolts are not apparent until you are on the route.
content.location: The Stinger Wall is a short way off the main trail leading up to the Kinsman west end crags. It is the first left (going up) at a prominent cairn with a pointed rock.  This map shows it: mountainproject.com/photo/1…  This is the right most route on the crag.  You will see the line of bolts.

content.description: Stung is a good little 12a with a very powerful crux for the grade. Climb up the ledge into the cave and take a bolt line up a steep arete feature out to the lip. Mantle up and clip the chains.
content.location: Stung is the steep arete feature going out of the left side of the cave at Stinger Wall.

content.description: Clip the first bolt of Stung, but trend right on jugs and slopers to a horn shaped jug by the 4th bolt. Shake out and do one hard move to the lip, then sink an excellent knee bar for a needed rest. Climb left along the lip to the mantle and anchor of Stung.
content.protection: 5 bolts. Clip the first bolt of Stung as a directional to prevent the hangers from turning.
content.location: To the right of stung, starting on an obvious right leaning line out the cave on large rails.

content.description: A short route going up into a corner. A mantle at the top lets you clip the anchors from a casual stance. Stick clip recommended. Once you know the moves well it makes for a good warmup for the harder routes at the crag. Be careful to pull your rope out of the rope eating flake before you lower off this one.
content.location: Left of Stung, located on the hill leading Honeypot

content.description: Honeypot was called open project in the Notches guidebook (pg 306), bolted by Pete Danen in the early 2000s. The bottom of this route can seep badly in the spring and feel strangely gooey, but if you catch it on a dry day you'll be one busy bee! Climb up to a jug and navigate through a horizontal filled with holds that could be better. Head straight up on bad holds through a wildly powerful move to a sloping jug, and then another very powerful move to a good hold and a rest ledge. Hang out for as long as needed, then trend right out a prow through one final boulder problem and a juggy finish.
content.protection: Bolts.   Double draws prefered on bolts 3 & 4, long slings prefered on 5 & 6. Stick clipping #2 makes the start more friendly.
content.location: Located left of the Stinger Wall cave in an alcove behind a boulder.

content.description:
Stick clip the first bolt. Start on a flake jug above your head and move through crimpy holds and powerful but precise moves toward a little lower angle terrain and a big rest ledge. After hanging out on the rest ledge, do big moves through another bouldery section to an anchor below the lip of the wall.

 Jon Sykes and Larry Boehmler aided this seam during the winter, and called it Seam's Cold 5.7 A3.(guidebook, pg 306, RHall NOTE) At the ledge they traversed to the left toward 5.7 terrain, but if you look carefully near the second bolt you can see an obvious drilled bathook hole from the initial ascent.
content.protection: 4 bolts, stick clip the first bolt.
content.location: Straight up a quartz seam to the left of Honeypot

content.description:
Hiking up the main climber's path to Kinsman West End's crags, the turn off to this crag is the first you encounter.  

  Home to about 6 climbs as of now.  Range from 5.6 to the 5.11d/5.12a "Stung".
